intro: Eriogonum douglasii var. sublineare, commonly known as the Douglas's buckwheat, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family and is characterized by its clustered, showy pink or red bracts that resemble flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats such as slopes and cliffs, thriving in full sun. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually covered in fine hairs, and it produces small, three-lobed seeds. This species is often found in chaparral and sagebrush ecosystems, contributing to local biodiversity.
